title: Add fig.margin for tuftehandout compatibility
body: Changed the knitr options to accept `fig.margin=TRUE` as this is the option used in the PDF `tuftehandout` template. This makes them (more) compatible, and preserves naming conventions. `marginfigure` is maintained for compatibility.

repo.description: Output formats for Tufte-style handouts in pdf and html for Rmarkdown
repo.name: tufterhandout

repo.description: Output formats for Tufte-style handouts in pdf and html for Rmarkdown
repo.name: tufterhandout

title: Custom CSS
body:
The pull request includes only small change in `html_tufte_handout` function. 
It enables custom CSS if `css` argument is provided in the front-matter. If there is no `css` argument it behaves as before (uses CSS from the **tufterhandout** package).

**New functionality**
User can now define a custom CSS in front-matter. For example:

```
output: 
    tufterhandout::html_tufte_handout:
      css: tufterhandout_my_version.css
```

**Rationale:**
I have a case where only minor changes to format are needed.
and I think it is easier to change the .rmd front-matter than changing R function.

repo.description: Output formats for Tufte-style handouts in pdf and html for Rmarkdown
repo.name: tufterhandout

repo.description: Output formats for Tufte-style handouts in pdf and html for Rmarkdown
repo.name: tufterhandout

title: Adding Tufte style fonts
body:
Hi Michael,

I don´t know if is in your plans add a _Tufte style_ font in your package, I think it would be great to have this option so I decided make this pull request. The font is URW Palladio and it is an opensource [alternative](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palatino#Availability) for the palladio font

You can see how it looks here: https://rawgit.com/jbkunst/r-posts/master/021-testing-tufterhandout-package/index.html

Hope you like it.

Regards
